Cis-pinane is an important chemical intermediate in the chemical industry, mainly originating from the selective hydrogenation product of α-pinene. However, the H2 molecules approach α-pinene in different directions to form different intermediates, resulting in low selectivity of cis-pinane. Therefore, designing new catalyst is supposed to be an efficient way to guide the orientation of products. Although many works have reported the new prepared catalysts can improve the selectivity of hydrogenated products, these works ignore the simplicity of the catalyst preparation process, especially in the carriers. In this work, the new high-efficiency and low-cost catalyst was prepared by introducing non-precious Ni-B reactive sites on a simple process-prepared carriers (Mesoporous graphite carbon nitride, MCN). After optimizing, the conversion and selectivity of α-pinene reached 98.9 and 99.9%. Combined with experimental characterization and density functional theory (DFT) calculation, these desiring results can be attributed to the synergy of Ni-B reactive sites and the large π system of MCN, which is beneficial to the absorption of reactants, and promote the production of target products (cis-pinane) follow a specific reaction route. This work demonstrates that the new prepared catalyst possessed excellent industrial potential to obtain natural product cis-pinane via catalytic reduction of α-pinene. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords α-pinene Mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride Ni-B alloy cis-pinane Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Originating from selective catalytic hydrogenation of natural products α-pinene, cis-pinane is an important intermediate which was widely applied in the preparation of fine chemicals [1]. Therefore, an efficient and stable catalytic reaction system needs to be constructed. However, commonly used Pd/C catalyst has a low selectivity to cis-pinane due to its excessive catalytic activity, which may cause the disintegration of four-membered ring of α-pinene and generation of unwanted impurities [2,3]. The detailed reaction pathway of main products in α-pinene hydrogenation is shown in Scheme 1 a [4]. In consequence, the preparation of low-cost and reusable catalysts with high catalytic activity and high selectivity is still a challenging task. Therefore, many work have been reported to solve this problem by preparing new catalysts to improve the selectivity of hydrogenated products [5]. As an important part of the catalyst, the carrier material is also important, which can stabilize reactive sites and provide reaction pathways for reactive substrates, thereby affecting reactivity, selectivity, and stability of catalyst [6]. Yang use AlPO4 as a stable carriers to support reactive sites Ni to achieve conversion of 94.8% and 95.1% selectivity to cis-pinane [7]. Xie prepared a mesoporous silica molecular sieves with Ru as catalyst to achieve a 99.9% conversion and a 98.9% conversion [8]. Although the reported carrier materials can effectively support these reactive sites, the preparation process of these materials is complicated, resulting in high cost and long time for catalyst preparation. Therefore, the preparation of simple, inexpensive and readily available carriers has become an ideal strategy for catalytic hydrogenation of α-pinene [9]. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is a promising metal-free material that consist of carbon and nitride [10,11]. As a catalyst carriers, g-C3N4 contains a large number of N elements, which can form a strong interaction with the ions to improve the stability of the active sites. In addition, g-C3N4 also has a large specific surface area to provide enough active sites and improve the molecular diffusion [12]. It is worth mentioning that C-N=C in g-C3N4 structure can form strong π-π interactions with C=C in α-pinene, which can promote the adsorption between the carriers and reactant molecules [13,14]. In addition, active site is also very important for catalysts. The formation of alloys with metals or non-metals has been proved to be a good way to improve the performance of catalysts [15]. The alloys prepared by combining different elements not only possess the advantages of each single element, but also suppress the disadvantages of each single element [16,17]. Therefore, in this work, we prepared a new g-C3N4 (Mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride, MCN) based amorphous Ni-B alloy catalyst by combining the advantages of MCN carriers and Ni-B alloy active site, and applied it in selective hydrogenation of α-pinene. After optimizing, the exciting results with 98.9% α-pinene conversion and 99.9% cis-pinane selectivity were obtained. Through experimental and DFT studies, we revealed the catalytic mechanism about hydrogen reduction of α-pinene to cis-pinane catalyzed by Ni-B@MCN, indicating that the synergistic effect of Ni-B active sites and the large conjugate π system of MCN can promote reactants to cis-pinane along a specific route. This work provides a new research strategy for subsequent research. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Urea (Macklin, AR, 99 wt%), sodium borohydride (Shanghai hushi laboratorial equipment Co, Ltd, 96 wt%), nickel chloride (Rgent, 98.0 wt%), α-pinene (Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products CAF, 75wt%), other chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of Mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (MCN) MCNX was prepared by non-templet method (Scheme 1b). X is represent the area of louver on aluminum foil, ammonia produced by deamination and condensation is the main factor for the formation of pore channels in the sample. By adjusting the size of the gas window on the crucible, the escape rate of ammonia can be changed, result in the change of the specific surface area of MCN. 20 g urea is added into a crucible which is tightly covered with Aluminium foil possessing X cm2 opening at 550°C for 4 hours. Before used, the prepared MCNX is ground into powder without further purification. 2.3 Preparation of Catalyst Ni0.8B0.2@MCN Ni-B amorphous alloy was embedded in the graphitic carbon nitride by impregnation method. 0.1 g MCN and 0.147 g NiCl2·6H2O were added in 20 mL deionized water under ultrasonic for 30 min to fully impregnated. 10 mL 1 mol/L NaBH4 was added into the above mixture at 70 °C under stirring and N2 protection. After the reaction, the obtained reaction product was washed and dried. The other referenced catalysts were prepared by the same strategy. 2.4 Catalyst reaction 8 mL α-pinene and 0.1 g catalyst are added in stainless steel, and then heated at 150 °C for 2 h under 4 MPa H2. After reaction, the obtained mixture was separated by centrifuged. The products were analyzed by a BJWLIYIQI GC-7806 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a 30 m EN-1 capillary column. The proportion of each component in the products were calculated by the area normalization method.. The conversion of α-pinene and the selectivity to cis-pinane were calculated by the following formula. C % = C α 0 − C α 1 C α 0 S % = C c i s 1 − C c i s 0 C α 0 − C α 1 C%: conversion of α-pinene, C α 0: concentration of α-pinene before reaction, C α 1: concentration of α-pinene after reaction, S%: selectivity to Cis-pinane, Cc is 0: concentration of cis-pinane before reaction, Cc is 1: concentration of cis-pinane after reaction. 2.5 Characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) tests were performed on a JEOL-1200 microscope operated at 100 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku D/max-2400 diffractometer with Cu-Ka anode radiation at 40 kV and 100 mA in the 2θ range of 10-90o with a scan speed of 2o/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a PHI-5702 instrumentm (Thermo Fisher Scientific-U. K; X-ray source: monochromated Al Ka, hv = 1486.6 eV; X-ray energy: 15kv, 150W; Spot size: 400 µm; Binding energies: C1s hydrocarbon peak at 284.60 eV). The porous structure of the catalysts was measured by a Micromeritics ASAP2020 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm at 77K. Before the measurement, the sample was degassed at 150 °C for 8 h in vacuum < 10−5 Pa. ICP-AES were taken on a Varian Vista Pro ICP-AES instrument running at 1200 W forward power. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The pore properties of new prepared MCN catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption. The isothermal adsorption curve of the synthesized MCN sample showed significant hysteresis, but this phenomenon was not observed in the MCN0 (Fig. 1 a), This results indicated that a large number of mesoporous structure appear in MCN samples synthesized by the louver control method [18]. Fig. 1b shows N2 adsorption-desorption curves for different Ni-B ratios. With the increase of B element content, the hysteresis loop becomes smaller. Excessive B doping may easily block the mesoporous channels of MCN0.1. The BET surface area, Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore sizes, and pore volumes are showed in Table 1 . The BET area of MCNx between 101.09 and 35.06 m2/g, depending on the area of the louver on the crucible during preparation. After Ni-B alloy was modified on MCN0.1, the BET area between 68.24 and 59.84 m2/g. BJH pore size distributions of samples are also presented in Fig. 1(c,d). Except for MCN0, the pore size of other samples is about 24 nm, After Ni-B alloy was modified on MCN0.1, sample pore size becomes smaller and more dispersed, and the increase of B content causes the pore diameter to be compressed to a smaller range. Which are attributed to the irregular pores caused by the amorphous alloy structure [19] The amount of loaded Ni-B elements were analyzed by ICP-AES, and the detailed parameters were shown in Table S1. The contents of Ni and B elements in all samples are about 25 and 5 wt%, respectively. The results indicated that the element content in the sample will not affected by carriers. After analyzing the data deeply, we can find that contents of B element slightly increase with the increasement amount of NaBH4 to limitation of around 5.54 wt%, which can be attributed to the special reduction and co-deposition process between Ni and B element [20]. As shown in Fig. 1e, the XRD results of MCNx with different pore areas all show (100) and (002) planes of carbon nitride MCN at 13.3 and 27.4°, which indicated different opening areas will not affect the formation of structural units of MCN. In Fig. 1f, the structures of the new prepared different Ni-B ratios catalysts were further confirmed by XRD. The diffraction peaks of samples at 13.3 and 27.4°can be attributed to (100) and (002) planes of MCN0.1 structure [21]. In addition, the peak position of 33.8° can match with the (121) crystal plane of B oxide (JCPDS 22-0745). A weak diffraction peak at 45.06°originates from the (111) crystal plane of Ni-B alloy modified on the surface of MCN carrier (JCPDS 06-0567). From the results of ICP-AES and XRD experiments, we can determine the formation of the catalyst. The morphologies of MCN0.1 and Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1 were investigated by TEM measurements (Fig. 2 a–d). Combined with SEM images(Fig. S1), the surface structure of MCN0.1 is rough and the related pore structure is obvious, which provides a good foundation for Ni-B active site. From the EDS mapping image (Fig. 2e–i), both C and N elements are evenly dispersed on the carrier, which clearly confirms B and Ni are evenly dispersed on the surface of carbon nitride, and the uniformly dispersed active sites can provide better catalytic effect. From SEM (Fig. S1) and TEM (Fig. S2) of different NiB ratios, it can be seen that with the increase of B element content, the metal clusters on the catalyst become more obvious, some pores are covered by Ni-B alloy. To further confirm the surface composition of the catalyst, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out. The typical C 1s, N 1s, O 1s Ni 2p and B 1s spectra of Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1 are shown in Fig. 3 . The full spectrum scanning of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 3a, compared with MCN0.1, the peaks of Ni, B and O were found in Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1, which confirmed the successful introduction of Ni-B, which confirms the existence of each element. In Fig. 3b, the C 1s spectrum of MCN0.1 and Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1, the peak at 282.25, 283.7, 285.5, and 286.15 eV, 288.3 eV can be assigned to the C–C bonds in adventitious carbon species, sp2-hybridized carbon in aromatic ring (C–N=C), C–N–C coordination, and C–O or C=O bonds from partial oxidation of C, respectively [22,23]. In the N 1s spectrum of MCN0.1 and Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1 (Fig. 3c), the peaks at 396.05, 397.55, 398.45 and 401.60 eV belong to pyridine nitrogen, which comes from the nitrogen atom in the triazine unit (C-N=C), 397.55 eV belong to quaternary nitrogen,which comes from one of the basic units in carbon nitride, the nitrogen atom (N(-C)3), whose intermediate ends are connected with carbon, 398.45 and 401.60 eV belong to (C-N-H) nitrogen comes from the unreacted edge of carbon nitride nitrogenous functional group, and amino satellite peak [24]. In Fig. 3d, the XPS spectrum for O 1s of Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1 show peaks at 528.7, 529.6 and 531.45 eV, which are corresponding to metal NiOx, BOx and C-O species, respectively [25]. The XPS spectra of B 1s and Ni 2p with different Ni-B loading ratios are shown in Fig. 3e,f, respectively. The peaks at 189.7 and 187.55 eV represent the binding energy of BOx species and B substance respectively [26], With the increase of B content, the orbital binding energy of B 1s shifts to the peak position, which indicate the electron transfer from B to Ni. The peaks of Ni 2p is at 871.1 and 853.3 eV represent the binding energy of NiOx species 2p1/2 and 2p3/2, and no single substance peak position of Ni is appeared, which indicating that Ni exists in the form of high oxidation [27]. With the increase of Ni content, the Ni 2p orbital binding energy shifts to the low peak position, which may be due to the electron transfer from B to Ni [28]. 3.2 The effect of Ni-B content on the reaction In order to investigate the effect of Ni-B element on the catalytic performance of catalyst, the catalysts with different Ni-B contents were applied in selective hydrogenation of α-pinene under same conditions. As shown in Table 2 , the increasement contents of B element can enhance the catalytic performance of catalyst to the maximum conversion 98.9% (Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1), after B is introduced, part of Ni2+ is transformed into Ni0, It is reported that the coexistence of Ni-based catalyst Ni and NiO/Ni(OH)2 has high hydrogenation activity [29], which can attributed to electron transport from B atom to Ni atom [30,31]. However, the catalytic performance of the catalyst began to decline, after further increase the content of B, probably due to excessive B atoms covering the Ni atoms [32]. 3.3 The effect of different catalyst carriers To investigate the catalytic performance of NiB@MCN with different catalyst carriers, Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0, Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1, Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.2 and Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.5 were applied in selective hydrogenation of α-pinene under same condition, and the related reaction results were presented in Table 2. Among them, Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1 exhibited the highest activity with 98.9% conversion of α-pinene and 99.9% selectivity of cis-pinane. The superior performance of Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1 can be attributed to π-π interaction between carbon nitride and α-pinene molecular [33,34], and higher surface area, which can provide, more abundant and stable reactive sites [35]. 3.4 The influence of reaction condition As shown in Fig. 4 a, there is no significant improvement for the conversion of α-pinene and selectivity of cis-pinane in the presence of MCN0.1 modified with less than 15 wt% Ni-B alloy. Then. the catalytic performance began to obviously rise to the maximum, when the load of Ni-B amorphous alloy is increasing from 20 to 30 wt%. After further increasing the amount of Ni-B alloy, the activity of the catalyst remains steady state. The reasonable explain is that 30 wt% Ni-B alloy can provide enough reactive sites. The influence of the temperature was evaluated in the experiment at the fixed value of 30 wt% Ni-B alloy (Fig. 4b). With the reaction temperature is increasing from 100 to 150 °C, the conversion of α-pinene and selectivity of cis-pinane can reach the maximum. After further increasing the temperature, the selectivity of cis-pinane decreased slightly, due to high temperature brings unexpected side reaction. The influence of the H2 pressure was addressed in the experiment at the fixed value of 30 wt% Ni-B alloy and 150 °C (Fig. 4c). When the H2 pressure rise from 1 MPa to 4 MPa, the corresponding conversion and selectivity of the reaction begin to rise to the maximum. After further increase the pressure of H2, the activity of the catalyst remains unchanged, due to 4 MPa H2 can provide enough H2 molecules on the catalyst surface to promote the hydrogenation reaction. After fixed value of 30 wt% Ni-B alloy, 150 °C and 4 MPa H2, the influence of reaction time was addressed from 80 to 140 min (Fig. 4d). The conversion and the selectivity of the product began to increase to the maximum at 140 min with prolonged reaction time. After further increasing reaction time, the selectivity of the reaction began to decline, which may be due to occurrence of side reactions during excessively long reaction times. In summary, the optimum conditions for preparing cis-pinane by hydrogenation of α-pinene are as follows: Ni-B alloy loading 30 wt%, reaction temperature 150 C, H2 pressure 4 MPa, reaction time 140 min under such reaction conditions, the conversion and selectivity of hydrogenation were 98.9 and 99.9%, respectively. 3.5 Theoretical studies about interaction between MCN and α-pinene The adsorption mechanism between MCN and α-pinene can be further studied by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation based on Gaussian09 software. Since the mainly structural units of MCN are triazine (MCNT) and heptazine (MCNH), the adsorption model is shown in Fig. 5 , four kinds of adsorption structures including: cis-[MCNT][α-pinene], trans-[MCNT][α-pinene], cis-[MCNH][α-pinene], trans-[MCNH][α-pinene] were used to study the formation of cis-pinane and trans-pinane, respectively [36,37]. 3.5.1 Adsorption quantum structure analysis According to the results of DFT calculation (Fig. 5 and Table S3), when the adsorption structure is cis-[MCNT][α-pinene], the interaction distance is 3.772 Å between the Triazine structure of MCN (MCNT) and α-pinene. In the same conditions, the distance increases to 3.873 Å when the molecule α-pinene interacts with MCNT by trans-[MCNT][α-pinene] adsorption structure. This result shows that the interaction between α-pinene and the structural unit of catalyst in cis-[MCNT][α-pinene] is stronger than that in trans-[MCNT][α-pinene]. This conclusion is further confirmed by the calculated absorption energy, -9.97 kj/mol for cis-[MCNT][α-pinene] and -4.16 kj/mol for trans-[MCNT][α-pinene]. When the structural unit triazine is replaced by heptazine with a larger conjugated system, the corresponding bond length is 3.724 Å for cis-[MCNH][α-pinene], 3.814 Å for trans-[MCNH][α-pinene] and the corresponding absorption energy is -11.82 kj/mol for cis-[MCNH][α-pinene] and -9.27 kj/mol for trans-[MCNH][α-pinene]. Compared with MCNT system, the corresponding bond length and absorption energy of MCNH system are obviously shortened and increased, which indicating that the absorption of α-pinene and MCN mainly depends on π-π stacking [38], and increasing the conjugated system is favorable for the catalyst adsorbing α-pinene molecules. The calculated results are consistent with the experimental reaction results. 3.5.2 The reaction of mechanism According to the results of the above experiments and calculations, the possible mechanism for hydrogen reduction α-pinene to produce cis-pinane catalyzed by Ni-B@MCN is shown in Scheme 2 . The whole catalytic process is divided into three stages: adsorption, hydrogenation and desorption. In the first stage, the catalyst adsorbs hydrogen and α-pinene molecules. The direction of No. 1 C and No. 2 C of α-pinene molecule is preferentially close to the catalyst, due to the synergetic effect of steric hindrance of No. 8 C and No. 9 C and the π-π stacking effect between of α-pinene and MCN. In the second stage of hydrogenation process,electrons are transferred from B to Ni to make Ni electron rich, due to the electronic effect between Ni and B elements. The electron rich effect of Ni adsorbs hydrogen and makes hydrogen become active hydrogen. One active hydrogen first carries electrons to attack No. 2 C in the double bond of α-pinene, making α-pinene become σ-complex intermediate [39], and then the electrons return to B to form an electronic circulation system, and then the second active hydrogen carries electrons in the same way to attack No. 1 C to complete hydrogenation process to obtain cis-pinane. In the final stage, the product desorbs and a new reaction cycle begins. 3.6 The reusability of catalyst The long-term stability of the catalyst is also an important standard for evaluating the performance of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the activity of the catalyst did not show a significant decrease after 6 times of recycling. In compared with the TEM images of fresh samples (Fig. 6b), the morphology of Ni0.8B0.2@MCN0.1 was almost unchanged after 6 cycles of use (Fig. 6c). At the same time, the elemental composition especially for active sites (Ni and B elements) of the catalyst also remained unchanged by the measurement of ICP-AES (Table S2). These results indicate that the stability of the catalyst structure is the main reason for the stable performance of the catalyst, which can be attributed to the tight attachment between Ni-B alloy and MCN carriers. 4 Conclusions In summary, the new high performance and low cost catalyst for the hydrogenation of α-pinene to cis-pinane was successfully constructed by loading amorphous Ni-B alloy on the surface of MCN prepared by a simple process. Compared with the others, the MCN carriers can significantly improve the performance of catalyst. On this basis, the conversion and selectivity of the catalyst were further improved by modifying the Ni-B alloy. After a series of optimizations, the performance of the catalyst reaches the α-pinene conversion of 98.9% and the α-pinene selectivity of cis-pinane 99.9%. In the meanwhile, the catalyst exhibits long-term stability. The exciting catalytic performance can be attributed to Ni-B active sites and the π-π interaction between the α-pinene molecule and MCN. Combined with the DFT results, we reveal the detailed reaction process andprovide an industrially promising strategy to obtain the target product cis-pinane. coredata.dc:description: Cis-pinane is an important chemical intermediate in the chemical industry, mainly originating from the selective hydrogenation product of α-pinene. However, the H2 molecules approach α-pinene in different directions to form different intermediates, resulting in low selectivity of cis-pinane. Therefore, designing new catalyst is supposed to be an efficient way to guide the orientation of products. Although many works have reported the new prepared catalysts can improve the selectivity of hydrogenated products, these works ignore the simplicity of the catalyst preparation process, especially in the carriers. In this work, the new high-efficiency and low-cost catalyst was prepared by introducing non-precious Ni-B reactive sites on a simple process-prepared carriers (Mesoporous graphite carbon nitride, MCN). After optimizing, the conversion and selectivity of α-pinene reached 98.9 and 99.9%. Combined with experimental characterization and density functional theory (DFT) calculation, these desiring results can be attributed to the synergy of Ni-B reactive sites and the large π system of MCN, which is beneficial to the absorption of reactants, and promote the production of target products (cis-pinane) follow a specific reaction route. This work demonstrates that the new prepared catalyst possessed excellent industrial potential to obtain natural product cis-pinane via catalytic reduction of α-pinene.
coredata.dc:title: Ni-B/Mesoporous Graphitic Carbon Nitride Catalyst Boosts Natural Product Cis-pinane Via Catalytic Reduction of α-Pinene
